Balochistan  faces  both  exogenous  and  endogenous  challenges.  Its  large 
landmass,  scattered  population,  and  extremely  low  population  density

scale  in  public  spending,  and  segmented  factor  and  output  markets.

Compounding  these  issues  are  weak  government  mechanisms  for 
planning and fiduciary control, resulting in waste and inefficient allocation 
of  resources.  In  addition,  the  government  of  Balochistan  (GOB)  is 
resource  constrained.  Its  own-source  revenue  generation  is  low,  and  the 
province  depends  heavily  on  federal  transfers.  The  province  suffers  from 
chronic  fiscal  deficits,  resulting  in  mounting  overdrafts  with  the  central 
bank. 
 
The lack of private sector participation in the development process further 
hurts growth prospects. While the province is rich in minerals, the private 
sector plays a limited role in the sector. The entry barriers are significant, 
and  these  are  aggravated  by  poor  physical  infrastructure  and  adverse 
security conditions. 
 
The  GOB  has  recognized  these  challenges,  and  has  made  improving  its 
fiscal  management  the  top  priority.  The  government  will  take  steps  to 
shore  up  its  own-source  revenues,  as  well  as  strive  to  obtain  the 
province’s  financial  share  from  the  federal  Government.  In  parallel,  it 
needs  to  strengthen  expenditure  management  through  prudent  fiscal 
policy,  controls  to  limit  waste  in  current  expenditures,  and  adoption  of  a 
realistic public sector development program. Expenditures at all levels will 
need  to  be  rationalized  to  ensure  that  public  spending  does  not  exceed 
resources, and does not cause excessive deficit financing. The GOB also 
recognizes the vast potential of the minerals sector, and the need to bring 
investments into the sector. 
 
In  the  areas  of  fiscal  decentralization,  public  resource  management,  and 
social  service  delivery,  ADB  has  supported  Balochistan  through  the 
Decentralization  Support  Program,  Balochistan  Public  Resource 
Management  Program,  and  Balochistan  Devolved  Social  Services 
Program. The GOB has requested ADB support for its agenda through the 
proposed  BRMP  II  to  deepen  these  reforms,  particularly  in  resource 
mobilization. 
 
The  long-term  impact  of  BRMP  II  is  higher  and  sustained  economic 
growth.  The  outcome  of  BRMP  II  will  be  improved  public  resource 
management,  characterized  by  higher  own-source  revenues  and  greater 
efficiency  in  resource  allocation  and  utilization.  Better  public  resource 
management  also  entails  improving  governance  in  key  sectors  in

Part  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  meet  the  mounting  pension 
liabilities in the province. The accumulation under the pension and general

future pensioners by ensuring that future pension payments will be met by 
a system with greater funding. The remaining loan proceeds will be used

local governments. Under the devolved structure, this translates into better

and sanitation services in subdistricts and villages. 
 
The benefits to be realized under BRMP II will be contingent on a number 
of assumptions and will be subject to risks. Therefore, mitigating measures 
have been integrated into the design of the Program. 
 
Macroeconomic Risks. Pakistan’s economy remains vulnerable to short-
term shocks as well as medium-term macroeconomic imbalances. Growth 
will slow down in 2008-2009, and recovery will be contingent on domestic 
as  well  as  global  factors.  The  Government  has  launched  a  medium-term 
stabilization  program  with  support  from  development  partners.  ADB  is  a 
lead  partner  through  its  support  under  the  Accelerating  Economic 
Transformation Program. This 4-year program cluster aims to facilitate the 
structural  transformation  of  Pakistan’s  economy,  leading  to  sustained 
economic growth of 8% per year between 2010 and 2020. 
 
Security  and  Political  Risks.  Continued  reports  of  instability,  attacks, 
plots, bombings, and even less-destructive activities such as protests and 
work  stoppages  affect  investors’  views  of  the  country’s  overall  stability. 
These  perceptions  affect  Balochistan  even  more,  given  the  security 
concerns in the province. Balochistan’s borders with neighboring countries 
are  porous,  smuggling  is  rampant,  and  law  enforcement  is  weak.  In 
addition, the province faces the risk of political and regulatory capture by 
the local elite and subsequent continuation of privileges. Although most of 
these political risks are beyond the control of a program such as BRMP II, 
the policy actions aim to set up transparent mechanisms for revenue and 
expenditure management, and to increase private sector participation. The 
introduction of  more  efficient  and  accountable processes  and  procedures 
under BRMP II will reduce the risk of political and regulatory capture. 
 
Governance,  Corruption,  and  Bureaucratic  Risks.  Transparent  and 
accountable processes and procedures may be resisted for two reasons. 
First,  the  bureaucracy  might  be  unwilling  to  alter  established  routines. 
Second,  moving  away  from  a  discretionary  to  a  rule-based  system  will 
likely  limit  corruption  and  discourage  rent-seeking.  The  resistance  to 
reforms might be stronger in the second case. BRMP II proposes specific 
measures that will become part of the legal framework, and will track their 
implementation.

signed  a  Letter  of  Intent  on  20  November  2008  seeking  a  $7.6  billion  stand-by  arrangement 
from the International Monetary Fund, as part of which broad-ranging macroeconomic reforms 
have been agreed upon.

A. 

Sector Description, Issues, and Opportunities 

7. 
The  public  sector  plays  an  essential  role  in  the  development  of  Balochistan.  GOB  has 
two main tasks: (i) providing the public investment and regulatory framework to facilitate private 
sector activity that drives economic growth; and (ii) delivering public goods to address key social 
needs,  such  as  education  and  health.  However,  government  inefficiency  has  hampered  this 
nexus,  weakening  the  province’s  economic  and  social  performance.  Figure  1  shows  how 
government inefficiency arises in Balochistan. It has two proximate causes: lack of fiscal space 
and  weak  institutional  capacity.  In  terms  of  fiscal  space,  GOB  depends  heavily  on  federal 
Government transfers, though having limited control over such transfers. Own-source revenues 
are low because of a narrow revenue base (arising from an underdeveloped private sector) and 
poor revenue administration. Expenditures, inherently high because of the larger cost required 
to  serve  sparsely  populated  and  scattered  communities,  are  constrained  by  poor  budget 
planning  and  coordination,  inefficient  subsidies,  increasing  pension  payments,  and  lack  of 
internal  controls.  As  such,  expenditures  are  poorly  targeted  and  prone  to  leaks.  Inefficient 
business processes and large but poorly skilled bureaucracies weaken the institutional capacity 
in the provincial and local governments. 
 
8. 
The 2007 public financial management and accountability (PFMA) assessment indicates 
the  urgency  of  improving  fiscal  and  financial  management  to  address  the  lack  of  fiscal  space. 
Areas with low ratings include tax assessment and collection, expenditure composition outturns, 
internal controls and account reconciliation, and weak tracking of resources for service delivery. 
A  summary  of  the  PFMA  assessment  is  in  Appendix  2.  As  such,  the  major  areas  for  policy 
intervention  would  be  in  (i)  revenue  administration;  (ii)  expenditure  management,  including 
budgeting, internal controls, and pension liabilities management; and (iii) governance in sectors 
with high growth and revenue potential, such as minerals.

Need for Better Fiscal and Financial Management 

 
9. 
Background.  Balochistan’s  fiscal  performance  is  weak.  After  running  surpluses  in  the 
second half of the 1990s, followed by narrow fiscal deficits in FY2001 and FY2002, the province 
has  experienced  widening  fiscal  deficits.  During  FY2003–FY2006,  expenditures  increased 
rapidly,  far  outpacing  revenue  growth.  This  resulted  in  large  budget  deficits,  which  peaked  at 
PRs8.5 billion in FY2004 (more than double that in FY2003). Higher development spending and 
increases in current expenditure transfers to local governments accounted for most of the rise in 
expenditures.  While  total  expenditure  growth  has  been  slower  in  Balochistan  than  in  other 
provinces,  the  ratio  of  recurrent  to  development  expenditures  has  continued  to  remain  high  in 
Balochistan  because  the  large,  sparsely  populated  province  necessitates  higher  operational 
expenditures.  In  FY2007,  an  across-the-board  gain  in  federal  transfers—more  than  PRs10 
billion  or  34%  more  than  the  federal  transfers  in  previous  fiscal  year—significantly  boosted 
provincial revenues and created additional fiscal space. This resulted in a sharp contraction of 
the budget deficit to PRs244 million in FY2007 (from PRs5.7 billion in FY2006), even as local 
government  current  expenditure  transfers  and  development  spending  continued  to  expand.  In 
FY2008,  the  growth  in  federal  transfers  tapered  off,  largely  because  of  declines  in  straight 
transfers,  but  provincial  expenditures  continued  to  rise,  mainly  for  debt  servicing,  transfers  to 
local governments, general administration expenditures, and development outlays.4 As a result, 
the budget deficit again widened to PRs3.3 billion. The sector analysis is in Appendix 3.

10.  Weak  Revenues.  Weak  own-source  revenue  generation  has  reduced  the  financial 
resources available for public spending. Balochistan’s own-source revenue, while improving in 
recent  years  (from  5.5%  of  total  revenues  in  FY2002  to  6.7%  in  FY2007),  remains  the  lowest 
among the four provinces of Pakistan. Recent inflows from land-related revenues have largely 
come  from  one-off  receipts  from  the  sale  and  long-term  lease  of  public  land.  Reforms  in  the 
motor vehicle tax (MVT) and provincial excise tax on liquor have led to higher collections. One 
of  the  BRMP  I  conditions  was  to  limit  the  property  tax  exemption  for  self-occupied  property  to 
139.35  square  meters  (1,500.00  square  feet).  Despite  an  executive  commitment  to  this 
condition by the previous coalition government in 2004, the Provincial Assembly increased the 
exemption  to  464.52  square  meters  (5,000.00  square  feet)  in  2005.  Nonetheless,  perhaps 
because  of  better  property  tax  collection,  revenues  from  property  taxes  did  not  decline 
significantly  with  the  higher  exemption.  Property  tax  collections  were  PRs38  million–PRs40 
million in FY2006–FY2008, slightly less than the PRs41 million collected in FY2005. However, 
revenue administration remains weak, both for tax and nontax sources. 
  
11.  Weak  revenue  performance  is  attributable  to  several  factors.  First,  procedures  give 
revenue  officers  substantial  discretion,  which  often  encourages  underreporting  and  corrupt 
practices. Stamp duties and property taxes are still not based on proper valuation  and annual 
rental  value  tables,  resulting  in  ad  hoc  and  discretionary  valuation  of  properties.  The 
assessment  of  urban  immovable  property  tax,  for  example,  depends  on  the  tax  officer’s 
judgment  of  the  rental  value  of  the  property.  For  the  stamp  duty,  no  valuation  rule  has  been 
formally prescribed.5 More important, while attempts to use valuation tables were made in the 
1990s, this was discontinued when a high court in 1996 disallowed the use of the tables. In the 
absence of a computerized system of record-keeping, it is difficult to assess if MVTs are being 
paid on time, and at the required rates.  
 
12. 
Second,  uncoordinated  procedures  between  the  Board  of  Revenue  (BOR)  and  Excise 
and  Taxation  Department  (ETD)  have  resulted  in  revenue  leaks  from  capital  gains  tax  on  the 
transfer  of  property.  The  BOR  registers  property  transfers  without  requiring  a  no-objection 
certificate  from  ETD.  In  the  absence  of  any  required  documentation  from  ETD  certifying  that 
taxes accruing to it, such as the property tax and capital gains tax, have been paid, properties 
are transferred without payment of these taxes. Unless the seller of the property voluntarily pays 
capital gains taxes, ETD is unable to track property transfers that are occurring in the province. 
 
13. 
Third, the concept of internal audits within the tax collecting departments is nonexistent 
in Balochistan. A mechanism to verify the accuracy of tax assessments and collection, as well to 
detect fraud, is not in place. Fiduciary arrangements are weak as the assessment and collection 
functions are entrusted to the same officer. As a result, opportunities for rent-seeking have been 
available for years. 
  
Fourth,  collections  are  not  properly  reflected  in  provincial  accounts.  Reconciliation  of

Poor Budgeting Processes. The current budget planning and preparation process is not 
conducive  to  proper  fiscal  discipline  or  allocative  efficiency.  Budget  preparation  is  mostly  an 
incremental  exercise  that  involves  little  consultation  with  stakeholder  departments  regarding

The  negotiations  on  allocations  occur  only  when  line  departments  submit  statements  of  new 
expenditure to the Finance Department. Most departments’ capacity for budget preparation is low. 
Systematic coordination among the Finance Department, Planning and Development Department 
(P&DD), and line departments for preparing current and development budgets is missing.  
  
16.  With  respect  to  the  development  budget,  the  weak  fiscal  position  has  compelled  the 
P&DD  to  refrain  from  starting  new  projects  until  ongoing  ones,  which  require  development 
funds, are completed. The development budget for FY2008 is PRs10 billion, equivalent to 19% 
of  total  provincial  expenditures—the  lowest  proportion  allocated  for  development  spending 
among  all  the  provinces.  However,  in  absolute  terms,  it  is  the  highest  ever  for  Balochistan. 
Funding  and  quality  of  spending  are  two  major  issues.  With  just  enough  revenues  to  cover 
current  expenditures,  the  development  budget  depends  on  debt  financing,  of  which  expensive 
overdrafts  from  the  central  bank  have  been  increasing  since  FY2005.  No  limits  or  norms  for 
deficit financing are in place, and debt liability management generally has been handled in an 
ad hoc manner. Because of P&DD’s weak capacity, the quality of public investments has been 
undermined by poorly planned and ad hoc loading of development schemes.  
 
The current level of aggregation in the budget prevents effective tracking of expenditures

Lack  of  Internal  Controls  and  Weak  Financial  Management.  Under  the  current 
financial management framework, internal controls necessitate verification of budget cover and 
pre-audit, as delegated by the Accountant General Office (AGO), by the treasury officers before

the 30 districts in Balochistan has a fully functional DAO office (in Uthal District). Yet, the bulk of 
public expenditures take place in at the district level. The Finance Department has promoted its 
treasury  officers  to  a  higher  grade,  and  designated  them  as  DAOs.  However,  they  have  not 
been  adequately  trained  in  the  accounting  and  are  unfamiliar  for  the  most  part  with  the  new 
accounting  model  and  chart  of  accounts.  Instead  of  treasury  officers  or  DAOs  preparing 
accounts  in  the  districts,  vouchers  are  sent  to  the  AGO  or  the  two  Accountant  General 
suboffices for subsequent classification. This results in delays in the submission of the monthly 
accounts, misclassification, and subsequent problems in reconciling receipts and expenditures. 
 
20. 
The GOB does not have full knowledge of its cash balances. Off-system funds, such as 
personal  ledger  accounts  and  assignment  accounts,  are  widely  used.  Unlike  regular  budget

operations  are  not  classified.  In  addition,  the  existence  of  these  accounts  tends  to  be 
overlooked  as  they  are  part  of  the  public  accounts  and  not  the  provincial  consolidated  fund.

21. 
Background. The GOB employs about 142,000 civil servants and pays pension benefits 
to  about  33,000  retirees  and  dependants.  The  GOB  provides  a  multi-pillar  old-age  protection 
system to its civil servants, consisting of a pension scheme and a general provident fund (GPF), 
similar to the old-age systems of the federal Government and the other provincial governments. 
Civil  servants  pay  monthly  contributions  to  the  GPF,  while  the  GOB  pays  pensions  from  its 
provincial budget. 
 
22. 
Growing  Pension  and  Employee  Benefit  Liabilities.  The  Finance  Department 
estimates that pension and GPF payments increased on average fivefold between FY1997 and 
FY2007.  The  group  insurance  payout  has  quadrupled  over  the  same  period.  For  FY2007,  the 
payments  were  estimated  at  PRs942.78  million  for  pensions,  PRs561.94  million  for  GPF,  and 
PRs99.56 million for group insurance. The estimate of the financial cost of the accrued pension 
and GPF liabilities will require an actuarial valuation.  
 
23. 
The  GOB  recognizes  that  its  pension  and  GPF  obligations  have  major  implications  for 
the  finances  of  the  province.  In  response  to  the  growing  fiscal  burden,  the  government 
established a pension section within the Finance Department. The main tasks of the section are 
to  quantify  the  pension  liability  of  the  GOB  and  to  prepare  cash-flow  projections  to  support 
budgetary allocations.  
 
24.

claim their pension and GPF entitlements.

Background.  Balochistan’s  mineral  resources  have  not  been  fully  tapped.  Although 
1,237 mining licenses have been granted in the province, the scale of operations remains small, 
limiting  production  volumes.  Independent  estimates  show  that  the  contribution  of  mining  to

sector has increased in recent years. However, the GOB is not ready to maximize the benefits 
from  the  possible  influx  of  mineral  investments  as  it  suffers  from  governance  problems  and 
lacks  sufficient  capacity  to  provide  geological  data,  contract  management,  and  environmental

facilitator of sustainable growth in the minerals sector is hampered.

C. 

Risks 

 

107.  The benefits to be realized under BRMP II depend on a number of assumptions and are 
subject to various risks. Therefore, mitigating measures have been integrated into the design of 
the Program. 
 
108.  Macroeconomic  Risks.  Pakistan’s  economy  remains  vulnerable  to  short-term  shocks 
as well as medium-term macroeconomic imbalances. Growth will slow down in 2008-2009, and 
recovery  will  be  contingent  on  domestic  as  well  as  global  factors.  The  Government  has 
launched a medium-term stabilization program with support from development partners. ADB is 
a lead partner through its support under the Accelerating Economic Transformation Program.26 
This  4-year  program  cluster  aims  to  facilitate  the  structural  transformation  of  Pakistan’s 
economy, leading to sustained economic growth of 8% per year between 2010 and 2020. 
 
109.  Security and Political Risks. Continued reports of instability, attacks, plots, bombings, 
and even less-destructive activities such as protests and work stoppages affect investors’ views 
of  the  country’s  overall  stability.  These  perceptions  affect  Balochistan  even  more,  given  the 
security concerns in the province. Balochistan’s borders with neighboring countries are porous, 
smuggling is rampant, and law enforcement is weak. In addition, the province faces the risk of 
political  and  regulatory  capture  by  the  local  elite  and  subsequent  continuation  of  privileges. 
Although most of these political risks are beyond the control of a program such as BRMP II, the 
policy actions aim to set up transparent mechanisms for revenue and expenditure management, 
and to increase private sector participation. The introduction of more efficient and accountable 
processes and procedures under BRMP II will reduce the risk of political and regulatory capture. 
 
110.  Governance,  Corruption,  and  Bureaucratic  Risks.  Transparent  and  accountable 
processes  and  procedures  may  be  resisted  for  two  reasons.  First,  the  bureaucracy  might  be 
unwilling  to  alter  established  routines.  Second,  moving  away  from  a  discretionary  to  a  rule-
based system will likely limit corruption and discourage rent-seeking. The resistance to reforms 
might  be  stronger  in  the  second  case.  BRMP  II  proposes  specific  measures  that  will  become 
part of the legal framework, and will track their implementation. 
 
111.  Capacity  Constraints.  Weak  capacity  in  the  province  is  likely  to  restrict  the  pace  of 
reform.  BRMP  II  focuses  on  a  limited  number  of  practical  actions.  Advisory  and  technical 
support through a TA grant will also be provided to the implementing agencies. 
 
112.  Fiscal  Sustainability  Risk.  Balochistan  has  limited  fiscal  resources,  generates  little 
revenue,  and  depends  heavily  on  federal  transfers,  which  account  for  about  93%  of  its  total 
revenue. At the same time, the GOB has a very high overdraft with the central bank. The GOB 
is  committed  to  increasing  its  own-source  revenue  to  9%  of  its  total  revenue  by  FY2010.  The 
pension  reform  and  other  expenditure  management  measures  will  help  manage  contingent 
liabilities and recurrent expenditures better.

B. 

Civil Service Pension System 

The GOB employs 142,629 workers and pays about 33,000 pension beneficiaries.14 The 
25. 
government provides a two-layer old-age protection system to its civil servants, consisting of a 
pension scheme and a general provident fund (GPF). In addition, the GOB provides for group 
insurance and a benevolent payment. Monthly contributions are collected from the civil servants 
gross pay for the GPF, group insurance, and benevolent pay. The pensions are paid from the 
provincial budget. All benefit payments are made on a pay-as-you-go basis.  
 
26. 
The pension scheme pays 2.33% of monthly final basic wage for each year of service, 
providing up to 70% final basic wage replacement. The workers must complete at least 10 years 
of service to collect a monthly pension benefit and up to 30 years of service can be counted in 
the calculations. Benefits can be collected after 25 years of service or upon reaching age 60. Up 
to  35%  of  the  pension  can  be  commuted  and  taken  as  a  lump  sum.  The  remainder  is  paid 
monthly basis as an old-age, survivor, or disability benefit. 
 
The  GPF  is  a  notional  defined-contribution  scheme.  Civil  servants  are  required  to 
27. 
contribute  3%–8%  of  their  basic  salary  to  the  GPF,  depending  on  the  level  of  income.  The 
contributions are registered as a book reserve with an administered rate of return (contributions 
are posted monthly to a record-keeping system, and an interest rate determined by the Ministry 
of  Finance  is  credited  annually  to  workers  accounts).  The  GOB,  which  uses  the  proceeds  as 
budgetary support, pays a higher-than-market markup (on average 11% per year) on a pay-as-
you-go  basis.  The  full  amount  of  a  worker’s  account  balance  (contributions  plus  annually 
credited earnings minus loans outstanding) can be withdrawn in a lump sum upon retirement.  
 
28. 
The monthly deductions from the civil servants gross salary for the group insurance are 
paid  as  premiums  to  the  State  Life  Insurance  Company  and  provide  a  death  benefit.  The 
benevolent  payment  covers  a  range  of  benefits,  such  as  a  monthly  payment  to  dependents 
upon death in service, marriage benefits, funeral grants, and education scholarships.

At retirement, the civil servant applies for the pension and GPF benefits with the AGO,

“ghost”  employees  and  “ghost”  pensioners,  are  believed  to  be  significant,  but  are  based  on 
anecdotal evidence. 
 

3. 

Weak Employee Benefit Structure 

35. 
The pension scheme for civil servants was inherited from the period of British rule, when 
the composition and size of the civil service was different. It has not been altered fundamentally 
for  more  than  a  century.  Certain  features  of  the  pension  scheme  have  led  to  inequitable  and 
arbitrary  outcomes  for  some  individuals.  At  the  same  time,  the  unfunded  pension  and  GPF 
liabilities  are  imposing  an  increasing  burden  on  the  budget  of  the  provincial  government. 
Pension  reform  is  required  to  develop  an  equitable,  adequate,  and  sustainable  retirement 
system that is tailored to the needs of a modern civil service. 
 
36. 
In  addition,  there  is  a  high  level  of  dissatisfaction  with  the  current  employee  benefit 
structure. When a civil servant dies, benefit payments overlap considerably. At the same time, 
civil  servants  feel  that  the  benefit  package  at  retirement  is  small,  offering  limited  replacement 
income  for  the  pensioner,  but  at  a  relatively  large  cost  to  the  government.  Streamlining  of  the 
employee benefit package seems advisable.

Need for Better Service Delivery in Key Social Sectors 

 
A. 
 
Balochistan’s  unique  geography  does  not  lend  itself  to  models  of  service  provision 
1. 
prevalent in more densely populated areas of the country. For example, almost all the attempts 
to provide relatively sophisticated services on a permanent basis at primary care health facilities 
have  been  futile.  Similarly,  efforts  at  providing  secondary  and  higher  school  facilities  in  areas 
not well serviced by public transport are not likely to succeed.  
 
2. 
Weak  Capacity  in  Local  Governments.  The  Devolution  Plan  of  2000  introduces 
extensive administrative and fiscal restructuring, as well as revisions to rules, regulations, and 
legislation.  It  also  places  considerable  demands  on  local  government  staff,  who  have 
traditionally had little exposure to financial management or decision making, and who typically 
do not have the required level of technical expertise. These problems are particularly acute in 
Balochistan because of its low level of human resource development, as well as its hierarchical 
social structure, which discourages innovation and initiative. 
 
3. 
Lack  of  Coordination  in  Training  Programs.  The  lack  of  coordination  of  training 
programs  in  the  province  hampers  human  resource  development.  For  instance,  the  Human 
Resource  Development  Directorate  of  the  Health  Department  is  the  focal  point  for  training 
activities  in  the  health  sector.  However,  the  Health  Department,  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs),  and  district  governments  conduct  training  without  the  knowledge  of  the  Human 
Resource Development Directorate. An integrated database has not been set up. Consequently, 
training programs overlap and scarce resources are wasted. 
 
4. 
Funding  Constraints  Faced  by  District  Governments.  District  governments,  which 
depend  heavily  on  the  transfers  from  the  provincial  government,  provide  basic  education  and 
health services. Each district’s allocation is based on current expenditure parameters. Transfers 
tend  to  be  limited  by  the  fiscal  constraints  faced  by  the  GOB.  Some  district  governments  are 
able to save on these one-line transfers, and fund development schemes. In general, however, 
the available funding is insufficient to finance significant improvements in the delivery of social 
services. The GOB implements health and education development schemes that cover multiple 
districts  or  receive  foreign  assistance.  Attempts  at  compensating  this  shortfall  through 
performance grants have also faced challenges. Access conditions for performance grants are 
fairly  stringent,  and  district  administrations  seldom  meet  all  the  requirements.  In  cases  where 
the  conditions  are  met  on  paper,  there  is  little  guarantee  that  they  will  be  implemented  in 
practice.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
In  2004,  the  government  of  Balochistan  (GOB)  released  the  Balochistan  poverty  reduction  strategy  paper  (B-PRSP), 
which  identifies  inclusive  growth  as  the  main  strategy  for  reducing  poverty  in  the  province.  It  is  underpinned  by  five 
pillars:  engendering  growth,  managing  the  scarce  water  resources,  achieving  governance  reforms,  improving  human 
development,  and  addressing  vulnerability  to  shocks.  Based  on  data  from  the  mid-1990s  to  2001,  the  B-PRSP 
indicates  that  poverty  in  Balochistan  is  severe,  due  in  large  part  to  the  interaction  of  social  (including  political), 
economic,  and  environmental  factors.  Social  indicators,  including  literacy,  life  expectancy,  and  health  activities, 
reportedly are among the lowest in the world. Economic challenges arise from the lack of economic activity, investment 
and  capital  accumulation,  compounded  by  poor  governance  and  weak  coordination  across  and  between  levels  of 
government. Furthermore, Balochistan covers 347,000 square kilometers with limited fertile land and water resources, 
and an extremely low population density, making the province a challenging environment for service delivery.  
 
The  country  strategy  and  program  update  for  Pakistan  2006–2008a  indicates  that  assistance  will  be  provided  to 
consolidate improvements in performance in the social sectors through province-based support for social sectors and 
provincial resource management programs. In this respect, the Second Balochistan Resource Management Program 
(BRMP  II)  is  aligned  with  the  country  strategy  and  program  update  and  earlier  programs  related  to  resource 
management and service delivery. BRMP and the Balochistan Devolved Social Services Program (BDSSP) aimed to 
assist the province with its strategy of inclusive growth to reduce poverty. The BRMP aimed to reform public finances 
and financial management by introducing poverty-related criteria in the allocation of development expenditures and the 
Public  Sector  Development  Program.  BRMP  also  aimed  to  reform  social  services,  particularly  in  the  health  sector. 
BDSSP aimed to assist Balochistan’s progress toward the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in health, education, 
and water supply and sanitation (WSS) by (i) increasing access to affordable, effective, and quality social services in 
the  public  and  private  sectors;  (ii)  reducing  disparities  in  access;  and  (iii)  strengthening  local  governments,  private 
sector,  and  communities  in  providing  services.  BRMP  II  continues  with  reforms  initiated  under  these  programs;  its 
objective  is  to  remove  growth  impediments  and  improve  fiscal  resource  mobilization.  The  resulting  improvements  in 
resource  flows  will  then  promote  further  improvements  in  social  service  delivery.  The  three  core  policy  objectives  of 
BRMP II are (i) improve public financial management, (ii) develop an affordable and sustainable pension and employee 
benefit system, and (iii) enhance government’s role as facilitator of minerals sector growth. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                              Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1. Key Issues 
 
According  to  primary  data  from  Pakistan’s  household  surveys  of  1998–1999,  2001–2002,  and  2004–2005,  the 
incidence, intensity, and severity of poverty have increased considerably in Balochistan.b The incidence of poverty in 
the province rose from 21.6% in 1998–1999 to 33.1% in 2004–2005. The worsening situation in rural areas accounted 
for the overall increase in the province; urban poverty levels remained stagnant. Although the increase in poverty from 
1998–1999 to 2001–2002 may be attributed to the severe drought that increased poverty across all provinces, poverty 
continued to rise over the subsequent 3 years. While statistics on the incidence of poverty are not yet available beyond 
2004–2005, some social sector statistics related to the MDGs seem to indicate improvement since 2004. According to 
the Pakistan social and living standards measurement survey (PSLM), which monitors the implementation of the MDGs 
and PRSP, education statistics have improved. Literacy increased from 37% in 2004–2005 to 42% in 2006–2007, while 
the  gross  enrollment  rate  at  the  primary  level  rose  from  65%  in  to  70%  in  that  period.  PSLM  statistics  for  the  health 
sector  indicate  an  increase  in  immunization  rates  among  children,  and  a  larger  percentage  of  children  received 
treatment for diarrhea. The rate of prenatal and postnatal consultations also increased.

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
BRMP  II  is  intended  to  address  government  inefficiencies  arising  from  weak  public  financial  management.  As  such, 
specific beneficiaries are not targeted. Reform under the program is expected to benefit the public, including the poor 
and vulnerable. One area that may have a social impact is addressing the weak financial position of the GOB, which 
results in insufficient resources to fund social expenditures. Ministry of Finance data on PRSP expenditures for FY2007 
show that education accounted for 6.7% of total spending, while health accounted for 21%—both are the lowest among 
all  Pakistan’s  provinces.  By  improving  resource  mobilization  and  allocation,  and  complementing  these  with  better 
internal expenditure controls, financial flows can effectively benefit the public. The GOB will be able to fully utilized its 
resources,  and  allocate  them  in  a  way  that  is  more  responsive  to  citizens’  needs.  In  addition  to  these  reforms,  the 
Government  will  be  encouraged,  through  policy  dialogue,  to  target  the  most  deprived  districts  in  the  allocation  of 
counterpart funds generated from the  loan proceeds through the  performance grant mechanism. The GOB and ADB 
discussed  the  possibility  of  expanding  the  scope  of  subprogram  2  of  BRMP  II  to  cover  reforms  on  social  service 
delivery to provide continuity to BDSSP. However, this will depend on the outcomes of BDSSP.
